title: An Introduction to R
text:
Learning outcomes
this course (hopefully) will ‚Ä¶

introduce you to using R ‚úîÔ∏è
help your research become more robust and reproducible ‚úîÔ∏è


this course (definitely) won‚Äôt ‚Ä¶

teach you everything there is to know about R ‚ùå
make you feel completely comfortable with R ‚ùå

title: An Introduction to R
text:
What is R?


environment for statistical computing, graphics and programming
created by Ross Ihaka and Robert Gentleman (1996)
maintained by international R-core development team
many, people contribute to R and the wider R community

title: An Introduction to R
text:
extra R information



more information can be found at
https://www.r-project.com
download R from the CRAN website
https://cran.r-project.org/

title: An Introduction to R
text:
why is R considered hard?

high initial investment in time to learn R
unfamiliar command line environment
frustrating (and sometimes) inconsistent syntax
analysis and figures can take longer (initially!)
relatively steep learning curve
it‚Äôs not actually that hard, just unfamiliar

title: An Introduction to R
text:
why you should learn R

it‚Äôs free and platform independent
it‚Äôs the software of choice for many students, academics, industries and charities worldwide
highly flexible and extensive
encourages you think about your research
questions, data and analyses

title: An Introduction to R
text:
why you should learn R


it allows you to keep an exact and reproducible record of your analyses
transparent
other people1 can
reproduce your analysis
easily share your code (GitHub)
open science

including the future you!

title: An Introduction to R
text:
why you should learn R


excellent graphics capabilities

title: An Introduction to R
text:
why you should learn R


employability
opportunity to get involved
with a fantastic and supportive
community

title: An Introduction to R
text:
GUI
#

title: An Introduction to R
text: RStudio

title: An Introduction to R
text: VS Code

title: An Introduction to R
text:
objects

commands are typed in the editor and then sourced into the console
at the > prompt


2 + 2

[1] 4



R is object orientated. You can create variable and assign value(s) to them


a <- 2 + 2
a

[1] 4

title: An Introduction to R
text:
objects

once created, operations can be performed on variables


a <- 2 + 2
b <- 3 * 2

a + b

[1] 10



very powerful and flexible

title: An Introduction to R
text:
functions

functions contain a set of instructions that allow you to perform a specific task(s)


1numbers <- c(2, 3, 4, 5, 6)
numbers

2mean(numbers)
3# estimating the variance
4var(numbers)


1

use the concatenate function

2

use mean function

3

this is a comment noted with #

4

use variance function

title: An Introduction to R
text:
functions

you can install user contributed packages to increase versatility and power
there are packages for almost anything
install packages from CRAN, Bioconductor and GitHub
packages are easy to install in R

title: An Introduction to R
text:
functions

Write your own functions
function to calculate standard error


1se_fnc <- function(x) {
2  std.x <- sd(x)
  nos.x <- length(x)
  se.x <- std.x / (sqrt(nos.x))
3  print(se.x)
}
4se_fnc(c(2, 3, 4, 5, 6))


1

define function name and arguments

2

calculate SD, number of obs, then SE

3

define function output

4

use your new function

title: An Introduction to R
text:
syntax

R is case sensitive A is not the same as a
commands are generally separated by a new line, but you can also use a ; (rare)
anything that follows the hash symbol # will be ignored by R. Use this to comment your code
a series of commands can be grouped using braces { }
write pretty code by following a code style guide

title: An Introduction to R
text:
help

when you need help for a function use help() or ?


help("plot")    # open help file for the function plot

or equivalently

?plot


or to search across all help files use help.search("plot") or ??plot

title: An Introduction to R
text:
help

Duckduckgo_it: Try online search You‚Äôll be surprised how many other people have probably had the same problem and solved it.
Stack Overflow: There are thousands of questions relevant to R on Stack Overflow
Here are the most popular ones, ranked by vote.
make sure you include a reproducible example to get the most useful advice. A reproducible example is a minimal example that lets others who are trying to help you to see the error themselves.

title: An Introduction to R
text:
tips

use R regularly
learning R is not a memory test, you have your R scripts
you don‚Äôt need to know everything about R
don‚Äôt stare at code for hours.
there are many ways to tackle a particular problem

the time invested now will be more than payed back in the future.

title: Simple statistics using R
text:
learning outcomes

introduce you to some basic statistics in R ‚úîÔ∏è
focus on linear models ‚úîÔ∏è
fit simple linear models in R ‚úîÔ∏è
check linear model assumptions in R ‚úîÔ∏è

title: Simple statistics using R
text:
Scratching the surface

many, many statistical tests available in R
range from the simple to the highly complex
many are included in standard base installation of R
you can extend the range of statistics by installing additional packages

title: Simple statistics using R
text:
an example



does seeding clouds with dimethylsulphate alter the moisture content of clouds (can we make it rain!)
10 random clouds were seeded and 10 random clouds unseeded
what‚Äôs the null hypothesis?







no difference in mean moisture content between seeded and unseeded clouds

title: Simple statistics using R
text:
Plotting the data

DataPlot



plot these data
interpretation?
what type of statistical test do you want to use?


clouds <- read.csv('data/clouds.csv')
str(clouds)

'data.frame':   20 obs. of  2 variables:
 $ moisture : num  301 302 299 316 307 ...
 $ treatment: chr  "seeded" "seeded" "seeded" "seeded" ...

title: Simple statistics using R
text:
t-test

t.test(clouds$moisture~clouds$treatment, var.equal=TRUE)


    Two Sample t-test

data:  clouds$moisture by clouds$treatment
t = 2.5404, df = 18, p-value = 0.02051
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group seeded and group unseeded is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
  1.482679 15.657321
sample estimates:
  mean in group seeded mean in group unseeded 
                303.63                 295.06 



reject or fail to reject the null hypothesis?

title: Simple statistics using R
text:
linear models in R

an alternative, but equivalent approach is to use a linear model to compare the means in each group
general linear models are generally thought of as simple models, but can be used to model a wide variety of data and exp. designs
traditionally statistics is performed (and taught) like using a recipe book (ANOVA, t-test, ANCOVA etc)
general linear models provide a coherent and theoretically satisfying framework on which to conduct your analyses

title: Simple statistics using R
text:
what are linear models?

t-test
ANOVA
factorial ANOVA
ANCOVA
linear regression
multiple regression
etc, etc

title: Simple statistics using R
text:
model formula

general linear modelling is based around the concept of model formulae



response variable ~ explanatory variable(s) + error



literally read as ‚Äòvariation in response variable modelled as a function of the explanatory variable(s) plus variation not explained by the explanatory variables‚Äô
it‚Äôs the attributes of the response and explanatory variables that determines the type of linear model fitted

title: Simple statistics using R
text:
linear models in R

the function for carrying out linear regression in R is lm()

-the response variable comes first, then the tilde ~ then the name of the explanatory variable

clouds.lm <- lm(moisture ~ treatment, data=clouds)


how does R know that you want to perform a t-test (ANOVA)?


class(clouds$treatment)

[1] "character"



here the explanatory variable is a factor

title: Simple statistics using R
text:
linear models in R

to display the ANOVA table use the anova() function


anova(clouds.lm)

Analysis of Variance Table

Response: moisture
          Df  Sum Sq Mean Sq F value  Pr(>F)  
treatment  1  367.22  367.22  6.4538 0.02051 *
Residuals 18 1024.20   56.90                  
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1



do you notice anything familiar about the p value?
(hint: see the output from the t-test we did earlier)

title: Simple statistics using R
text:
linear models in R

we have sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis (as before)
therefore, there is a significant difference in the mean moisture content between clouds that were seeded and unseeded clouds
do we accept this inference?
what about assumptions?
we could use Shapiro-Wilks and F tests as before
much better to assess visually by plotting the residuals

title: Simple statistics using R
text:
Plotting residuals

clouds.lm is a linear model object we can do stuff with it
we can use the plot() function directly to display residual plots
normality assumption
equal variance assumption
unusual or influential observations

title: Simple statistics using R
text:
Plotting residuals

par(mfrow = c(2, 2), bg = "#FFFFFFCC")
plot(clouds.lm)

title: Simple statistics using R
text:
other linear models








traditional name
model formula
R code




simple linear regression
Y ~ X1 (continuous)
lm(Y ~ X)


one-way ANOVA
Y ~ X1 (categorical)
lm(Y ~ X)


two-way ANOVA
Y ~ X1 (cat) + X2 (cat)
lm(Y ~ X1 + X2)


ANCOVA
Y ~ X1 (cat) + X2 (cont)
lm(Y ~ X1 * X2)


multiple regression
Y ~ X1 (cont) + X2 (cont)
lm(Y ~ X1 + X2)


factorial ANOVA
Y ~ X1 (cat) * X2 (cat)
lm(Y ~ X1 * X2)

title: On the R-way to hell
text:
Manual
Here is a link to the the introduction to R manual: On the R-way to hell

title: On the R-way to hell
text:
About slides  and notes 

Slides 
Slides in revealjs format (html). If you want then as a pdf (note you might loose some functionality or contents due to tabs and scroll sections):

Open the slides in your browser from a link on this page
Press e to get into the PDF export mode (?print-pdf should appear near the end of the url and white borders should appear)
Open the in-browser print dialog (CTRL/CMD+P).
Change the Destination setting to Save as PDF.
Change the Layout to Landscape.
Change the Margins to None.
Enable the Background graphics option (if you want it)
Click Save üéâ



Notes 
Content of the slides in html format as a self-contained downloadable file and including tabs and scroll sections.
More importantly, notes have the commenting and annotateing tools activated via https://hypothes.is/. If you create a free account , you can annotate and comment slides as well as share your annotations/comments with the public or via private or public groups.

title: Julien Martin
text:
Julien is an Associate Professor at the University of Ottawa and has been teaching (and learning) R for the last 15 years.
I created the websites using Quarto, R, revealjs, mermaid.js and graphViz. I developed the theme for the slides based on the xaringan blackboard theme.

title: Biostats uOttawa
text:
EnglishFran√ßais



Biostatistic courses at uOttawa
This regroup the different resources developed for the biostatistic courses at the university of Ottawa by Julien Martin

Applied biostatistics with R (BIO 4X58) 

Offered to both undergraduate and graduate students in english and french
Prerequisite:

an introduction class to statisticis is good to have
No (or limited) knowledge of R and no (or limited) knowledge of stats expected.

BIO4158 english (Course site / Course manual)
BIO4558 french (Course site / Course manual)



Advanced biostatistics and open science (BIO 8940) 

Bilingual course for graduate students
Prerequisite:

a functional knowledge of R (loading data, running basic linear models, and making plots)
a good understanding of linear models
essentially Bio8940 is a great next steps after completing Bio4x58.

Course site / Course manual




Intro to R book: On the R-way to hell 
This is an introduction to R book with a multilingual approach. The book is covering an intorduction to the basic use of R (data loading, wrangling and plotting), as well as simple stats, programming, use of github and R markdown /Quarto with R Studio and VS code.
The book (still under development) is available in English and French. I will add more languages later this year hopefully with help of volunteers.
Here are also a few slides about an intro to R only in english (slides).


Statistical consulting 
As Part of my service in the Biology department, I provide statistical consulting. Please just contact me to book an appointment to discuss your stat problems.
Please bring with you (or send me in advance):

your data
your R code (should at least load the data into R)
a clear working hypothesis

Statistical consulting does not mean that you have to add me as a co-author. I just ask that you add me to the ‚ÄúAcknowledgements‚Äù of your thesis and manuscript/article. Repeated consulting on the same problem and my implication on developing project specific coding/analysis might lead to co-authorship, but this usually all comes naturally and is always discussed openly with the student(s) and PI(s). As yet, I have never requested to become a co-author and I was offered co-authorship for 3 manuscripts over > 50 projects discussed.




Cours de biostatistique √† uOttawa
Le site regroupe les diff√©rentes ressources d√©velopp√©es par Julien Martin pour les cours de biostatistiques √† uOttawa

Biostatistiques appliqu√©es avec R (BIO 4X58) 

Cours offerts aux √©tudiant au baccaulaur√©at et aux √©tudiants gradu√©s en anglais et en fran√ßais
Pr√©-requis:

cours d‚Äôintroduction au statistiques recommand√©e
Aucune connaissance de R et des statistiques requises

BIO4158 anglais (cours / manuel)
BIO4558 fran√ßais (cours / manuel)



Biostatistiques avanc√©es et science ouverte (BIO8940) 

Cours bilingues offerts aux √©tudiants gradu√©s
Pr√©-requis:

connaissances fonctionelle de R (chargement de donn√©es, graphique et statistiques de bases)
bonne compr√©hension des mod√®les lin√©aires
Essentiellement Bio4x58

cours / manuel




Livre d‚Äôintroduction √† R: Sur le chemin de l‚Äôenf-R 
Il s‚Äôagit d‚Äôun livre d‚Äôintroduction √† R avec une approche multilingue. Le livre couvre une introduction √† l‚Äôutilisation de base de R (chargement de donn√©es, manipulation et tra√ßage), ainsi que des statistiques simples, la programmation, l‚Äôutilisation de github et de R markdown /Quarto avec R Studio et VS code.
Le livre (encore en d√©veloppement) est disponible en anglais et fran√ßais. J‚Äôajouterai d‚Äôautres langues plus tard dans l‚Äôann√©e, avec l‚Äôaide de volontaires.
Voici √©galement quelques diapositives sur une introduction √† R uniquement en anglais (slides).


Consultations en statistique 
Je fournis des services de consultation en biostatistique dans le cadre de mon service au d√©partement de Biologie. Pour discuter de vos probl√®mes en statistiques, veuillez simplement me contacter pour prendre un rendez-vous.
Veuillez avoir avec vous (ou me l‚Äôenvoyer en avance):

vos donn√©es
votre code R (au minimum capable de charger les donn√©es)
une hypoth√®se de travail ou question biologique claire

Une consultation statistiques n‚Äôimplique pas de m‚Äôajouter en tant ue que co-auteur. Je demande simplement que vous m‚Äôajoutiez au Remerciements/Acknowledgements de votre th√®se et/ou manuscript. Je reconnais que dans certains cas, e.g.¬†nombres r√©p√©t√©es de consultations sur le m√™me projet incluant le d√©veloppement de code et analyse sp√©cifique au projet, je peux devenir co-auteur sur un projet. Cette discussion a habituellement lieu de mani√®re naturelle et √† toujours lieu de mani√®re ouverte et ransparente avec les personnes impliqu√©es, √©tudiant.e.s et PI.s. Jusqu‚Äô√† maintenant, je n‚Äôai jamais demand√© √† √™tre co-auteur, et je suis devenu co-auteur sur 3 articles et j‚Äôai √©t√© consult√© pour plus de 50 projets.

title: Getting the data in R
text:
recognise different types of data in R ‚úîÔ∏è
understand some different data structures ‚úîÔ∏è
learn how to import data into R ‚úîÔ∏è
learn how to manipulate data in R ‚úîÔ∏è
learn how to export data from R ‚úîÔ∏è

title: Getting the data in R
text:
recognise different types of data in R ‚úîÔ∏è
understand some different data structures ‚úîÔ∏è
learn how to import data into R ‚úîÔ∏è
learn how to manipulate data in R ‚úîÔ∏è
learn how to export data from R ‚úîÔ∏è

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.2 types of data in R


six types of data in R

numeric - 1.618, 3.14, 2.718
integers - 1, 2, 3, 42, 101
logical - TRUE or FALSE
character - ‚ÄúBI5009‚Äù, ‚ÄúBlue‚Äù
complex
raw

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.3 data structures


five data structures

vector
matrix
array
data frame
list

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.4 vectors



one dimensional collection elements
can contain all data types
all elements must be of the same type

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.5 matrices and arrays



a vector with extra dimensions
again, objects must be of the same type
arrays are multidimensional matrices


mat.1 <- matrix(1:12, nrow=4)
mat.1

     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]    1    5    9
[2,]    2    6   10
[3,]    3    7   11
[4,]    4    8   12





array.1 <- array(1:16, dim=c(2,4,2))

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.6 data frames

most commonly used data structure for statistical data analysis
powerful 2-dimensional vector holding structure
dataframes can hold vectors of any of the basic classes of data



   treat nitrogen block height weight leafarea shootarea flowers
1    tip   medium     1    7.5   7.62     11.7      31.9       1
2    tip   medium     1   10.7  12.14     14.1      46.0      10
3    tip   medium     1   11.2  12.76      7.1      66.7      10
4    tip   medium     1   10.4   8.78     11.9      20.3       1
5    tip   medium     1   10.4  13.58     14.5      26.9       4
6    tip   medium     1    9.8  10.08     12.2      72.7       9
7    tip   medium     1    6.9  10.11     13.2      43.1       7
8    tip   medium     1    9.4  10.28     14.0      28.5       6
9    tip   medium     2   10.4  10.48     10.5      57.8       5
10   tip   medium     2   12.3  13.48     16.1      36.9       8

title: Getting the data in R
text: 0.7 tidy data

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.8 importing data



simplest method is to use spreadsheet
and then import data into R
save as a comma separated file (*.csv)

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.9 Importing data tips

missing data represented with NA or empty cells. Do not mixed both
No spaces in names (use underscore if needed)
no uppercase
keep variable names short & informative

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.10 importing data

the read.table() function is the workhorse with format specified function to make coding faster

  petunia <- read.table('data/flowers.csv', header = TRUE, sep = ',')





petunia
name of the new object


read.table()
function use tot read tha data


‚Äòdata/flowers.csv‚Äô
relative path name to the data file


header = TRUE
first line contain columns names


sep = ‚Äò,‚Äô
columns sparated by commas

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.11 importing data

sometimes columns are separated by tabs, sep = "\t"

petunia <- read.table('data/flowers.csv', header = TRUE, sep = '\t')

you can use format specific functions

petunia <- read.csv('flowers.csv')      # if comma-separated 
petunia <- read.delim('flowers.txt')      # if tab-separated

functions in the foreign package allows you to import files of other formats (i.e.¬†from SAS, SPSS, Minitab etc)
use the readxl or readODS package to directly import MS Excel or LO calc spreadsheets directly

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.12 importing data

to view the contents of a data frame, type it‚Äôs name
rarely a good idea as just fills up your console
use the head() and tail() to see first/last 6 lines



[1] flowers


  treat nitrogen block height weight leafarea shootarea flowers
1   tip   medium     1    7.5   7.62     11.7      31.9       1
2   tip   medium     1   10.7  12.14     14.1      46.0      10
3   tip   medium     1   11.2  12.76      7.1      66.7      10
4   tip   medium     1   10.4   8.78     11.9      20.3       1
5   tip   medium     1   10.4  13.58     14.5      26.9       4
6   tip   medium     1    9.8  10.08     12.2      72.7       9

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.13 data wrangling

str() function: data frame dimensions, list of variables, type of variables


> str(flowers)

'data.frame':   96 obs. of  8 variables:
 $ treat    : chr  "tip" "tip" "tip" "tip" ...
 $ nitrogen : chr  " medium" " medium" " medium" " medium" ...
 $ block    : int  1 1 1 1 1 1 1 1 2 2 ...
 $ height   : num  7.5 10.7 11.2 10.4 10.4 9.8 6.9 9.4 10.4 12.3 ...
 $ weight   : num  7.62 12.14 12.76 8.78 13.58 ...
 $ leafarea : num  11.7 14.1 7.1 11.9 14.5 12.2 13.2 14 10.5 16.1 ...
 $ shootarea: num  31.9 46 66.7 20.3 26.9 72.7 43.1 28.5 57.8 36.9 ...
 $ flowers  : int  1 10 10 1 4 9 7 6 5 8 ...

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.14 data wrangling

names() function: vector of variable names


> names(flowers)

[1] "treat"     "nitrogen"  "block"     "height"    "weight"    "leafarea" 
[7] "shootarea" "flowers"

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.16 positional index

provide the row and column position of the data you wish to extract
index can either be a positional index or a logical index


flowers[1, 4]      # extract value of first row and 4th column

[1] 7.5



extract multiple elements by supplying vectors


flowers[1:3, 1:4]      # extract rows 1 to 3 and columns 1 to 4

  treat nitrogen block height
1   tip   medium     1    7.5
2   tip   medium     1   10.7
3   tip   medium     1   11.2

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.17 positional index

another example


1flowers[c(3, 8, 20), c(1, 4, 5, 6)]


1

rows 3, 8 and 20 and columns 1, 4, 5 and 6




   treat height weight leafarea
3    tip   11.2  12.76      7.1
8    tip    9.4  10.28     14.0
20   tip    8.5  14.33     13.2



can assign these extracted values to another object if you want
new object inherits data.frame class

flowers_red <- flowers[c(3, 8, 20), c(1, 4, 5, 6)]
flowers_red

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.18 positional index

we can use a short cut if we want all rows or all columns extracted
omitting the column index is shorthand for ‚Äòall columns‚Äô


> flowers[1:3, ]

  treat nitrogen block height weight leafarea shootarea flowers
1   tip   medium     1    7.5   7.62     11.7      31.9       1
2   tip   medium     1   10.7  12.14     14.1      46.0      10
3   tip   medium     1   11.2  12.76      7.1      66.7      10



omitting the row index is shorthand for ‚Äòall rows‚Äô


> flowers[, 1:3]

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.19 positional index

an alternative method to select columns is to name the columns directly for columnIndex


> flowers[1:10, c('treat', 'nitrogen', 'leafarea', 'shootarea')]

   treat nitrogen leafarea shootarea
1    tip   medium     11.7      31.9
2    tip   medium     14.1      46.0
3    tip   medium      7.1      66.7
4    tip   medium     11.9      20.3
5    tip   medium     14.5      26.9
6    tip   medium     12.2      72.7
7    tip   medium     13.2      43.1
8    tip   medium     14.0      28.5
9    tip   medium     10.5      57.8
10   tip   medium     16.1      36.9

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.20 logical index

we can also extract rows based on a logical test
example, all rows where the height variable is greater than 12


> flowers[flowers$height > 12,]

   treat nitrogen block height weight leafarea shootarea flowers
10   tip   medium     2   12.3  13.48     16.1      36.9       8
17   tip     high     1   12.6  18.66     18.6      54.0       9
21   tip     high     1   14.1  19.12     13.1     113.2      13
32   tip     high     2   17.2  19.20     10.9      89.9      14
38   tip      low     1   12.3  11.27     13.7      28.7       5



or where leafarea is equal to 8.7


flowers[flowers$leafarea == 8.7,]

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.21 logical index

we can combine logical tests using the & symbol (AND) or the | symbol (OR)
example, extract all rows where height is > 10.5 and nitrogen is equal to "medium"


flowers[flowers$height > 10.5 & flowers$nitrogen == 'medium',]


or height is greater than 12.3 OR less than 1.8


flowers[flowers$height > 12.3 | flowers$height < 1.8,]

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.22 exporting data frames

the write.csv() function exports data frames to an external file



write.csv(flowers, 'flowers2.csv', row.names = FALSE)



saves flowers data frame to a file named ‚Äòflowers.csv‚Äô
row.names = FALSE argument supresses the row names in the file

title: Getting the data in R
text:
0.23 other options

there are many other options for importing and exporting data in R
the fread() and fwrite() functions in the read.table package are blazingly fast
the read_csv() and write_csv() (and other related) functions from the readr package for tidyverse alternatives
if you have a lot of data (I mean alot!) then take a look at the ff and bigmemory packages

importing data

Importing data tips

missing data represented with NA or empty cells. Do not mixed both
No spaces in names (use underscore if needed)

importing data

the read.table() function is the workhorse with format specified function to make coding faster

[1] flowers


  treat nitrogen block height weight leafarea shootarea flowers
1   tip   medium     1    7.5   7.62     11.7      31.9       1

title: Getting the data in R
text:
data wrangling

str() function: data frame dimensions, list of variables, type of variables


> str(flowers)

'data.frame':   96 obs. of  8 variables:
 $ treat    : chr  "tip" "tip" "tip" "tip" ...
 $ nitrogen : chr  " medium" " medium" " medium" " medium" ...
 $ block    : int  1 1 1 1 1 1 1 1 2 2 ...
 $ height   : num  7.5 10.7 11.2 10.4 10.4 9.8 6.9 9.4 10.4 12.3 ...
 $ weight   : num  7.62 12.14 12.76 8.78 13.58 ...
 $ leafarea : num  11.7 14.1 7.1 11.9 14.5 12.2 13.2 14 10.5 16.1 ...
 $ shootarea: num  31.9 46 66.7 20.3 26.9 72.7 43.1 28.5 57.8 36.9 ...
 $ flowers  : int  1 10 10 1 4 9 7 6 5 8 ...

title: Getting the data in R
text:
data wrangling

names() function: vector of variable names


> names(flowers)

[1] "treat"     "nitrogen"  "block"     "height"    "weight"    "leafarea" 
[7] "shootarea" "flowers"

title: Getting the data in R
text:
positional index

provide the row and column position of the data you wish to extract
index can either be a positional index or a logical index


flowers[1, 4]      # extract value of first row and 4th column

[1] 7.5



extract multiple elements by supplying vectors


flowers[1:3, 1:4]      # extract rows 1 to 3 and columns 1 to 4

  treat nitrogen block height
1   tip   medium     1    7.5
2   tip   medium     1   10.7
3   tip   medium     1   11.2

title: Getting the data in R
text:
positional index

another example


1flowers[c(3, 8, 20), c(1, 4, 5, 6)]


1

rows 3, 8 and 20 and columns 1, 4, 5 and 6




   treat height weight leafarea
3    tip   11.2  12.76      7.1
8    tip    9.4  10.28     14.0
20   tip    8.5  14.33     13.2



can assign these extracted values to another object if you want
new object inherits data.frame class

flowers_red <- flowers[c(3, 8, 20), c(1, 4, 5, 6)]
flowers_red

title: Getting the data in R
text:
positional index

we can use a short cut if we want all rows or all columns extracted
omitting the column index is shorthand for ‚Äòall columns‚Äô


> flowers[1:3, ]

  treat nitrogen block height weight leafarea shootarea flowers
1   tip   medium     1    7.5   7.62     11.7      31.9       1

omitting the row index is shorthand for ‚Äòall rows‚Äô


> flowers[, 1:3]

title: Getting the data in R
text:
positional index

an alternative method to select columns is to name the columns directly for columnIndex


> flowers[1:10, c('treat', 'nitrogen', 'leafarea', 'shootarea')]

   treat nitrogen leafarea shootarea
1    tip   medium     11.7      31.9
2    tip   medium     14.1      46.0
3    tip   medium      7.1      66.7
4    tip   medium     11.9      20.3
5    tip   medium     14.5      26.9

8    tip   medium     14.0      28.5
9    tip   medium     10.5      57.8

title: Getting the data in R
text:
logical index

we can also extract rows based on a logical test
example, all rows where the height variable is greater than 12


> flowers[flowers$height > 12,]

   treat nitrogen block height weight leafarea shootarea flowers
10   tip   medium     2   12.3  13.48     16.1      36.9       8
17   tip     high     1   12.6  18.66     18.6      54.0       9
21   tip     high     1   14.1  19.12     13.1     113.2      13
32   tip     high     2   17.2  19.20     10.9      89.9      14
38   tip      low     1   12.3  11.27     13.7      28.7       5



or where leafarea is equal to 8.7


flowers[flowers$leafarea == 8.7,]

title: Getting the data in R
text:
logical index

we can combine logical tests using the & symbol (AND) or the | symbol (OR)
example, extract all rows where height is > 10.5 and nitrogen is equal to "medium"


flowers[flowers$height > 10.5 & flowers$nitrogen == 'medium',]


or height is greater than 12.3 OR less than 1.8


flowers[flowers$height > 12.3 | flowers$height < 1.8,]

title: Getting the data in R
text:
exporting data frames

the write.csv() function exports data frames to an external file



write.csv(flowers, 'flowers2.csv', row.names = FALSE)



saves flowers data frame to a file named ‚Äòflowers.csv‚Äô
row.names = FALSE argument supresses the row names in the file

title: Getting the data in R
text:
other options

there are many other options for importing and exporting data in R
the fread() and fwrite() functions in the read.table package are blazingly fast
the read_csv() and write_csv() (and other related) functions from the readr package for tidyverse alternatives
if you have a lot of data (I mean alot!) then take a look at the ff and bigmemory packages
